com.isoterik.mgdx

Class Scene

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.isoterik.mgdx.Scene
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.badlogic.gdx.physics.box2d.ContactListener
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TiledMapScene

    public class Scene
extends java.lang.Object
implements com.badlogic.gdx.physics.box2d.ContactListener
    A Scene contains the GameObjects of your game. Think of each Scene as a unique level of your game. Every scene has its own InputManager for managing input.

    A GameCamera is used to display a portion of the scene or the whole scene at a time. While its possible to use multiple cameras, scenes currently support only one main camera for projection.

    GameObjects are manged with Layers. Layers are processed top-down; layers added first are processed first (this can be used to manipulate how GameObjects are rendered.) A default layer is provided so you don't have to use layers if you don't need to.

    Physics is also managed by the scene. Box2D is used to manage 2D physics simulations. For Box2D, every scene has its own instance of World. The scene provides its own implementation of ContactListener; so manually calling World.setContactListener(ContactListener) will prevent some minGdx physics features from working correctly. If you need to extend the default implementation of the ContactListener, simply override the needed methods and don't forget to call the super class's implementation!.

    There is currently no support for 3D physics simulation.

    Every scene has a Stage instance for working with UI elements. The stage is already setup to update, receive input and render; you don't have do these yourself.

    • Method Detail

      • isStackable

        public boolean isStackable()
        Returns:
        whether this scene can be stacked

      • setStackable

        public void setStackable(boolean stackable)
        Stackable scenes are scenes that can be added to a stack when the SceneManager switches scenes. Instances of stackable scenes are always retained and can be switched back to using the same instance. Scenes that are not stackable are disposed as soon as the scene manager switches from them.

        A good rule of thumb:

        • If the scene takes a considerable amount of time to load resources and the scene is very likely to be returned to then it may be a good choice to make it stackable. That way the resources are loaded only once.
        • If the scene is very resource intensive and other scenes need to be loaded then it may be a good idea to NOT make it stackable. That way the resources allocated by that scene is disposed as soon as it is no longer needed.
        • If the scene is a UI scene (like a main menu scene) then it may be a good idea to make it stackable since UI scenes are usually visited many times.

        Scenes are stackbale by default

        Parameters:
        stackable - whether this scene should be stackable

      • setPhysicsTimeStep

        public void setPhysicsTimeStep(float physicsTimeStep)
        Currently the physics engine simulates at a fixed time step of (1f / 60f) 60 frames per second. Use this method to change it if you have to.
        Parameters:
        physicsTimeStep - the fixed time step for physics simulation.

        public void setRenderPhysicsDebugLines(boolean renderPhysicsDebugLines)

        Parameters:
        renderPhysicsDebugLines - whether physics bodies debug lines should be rendered.

      • setRenderCustomDebugLines

        public void setRenderCustomDebugLines(boolean renderCustomDebugLines)
        Custom debug lines can be rendered around game objects. This is useful for debugging purposes. This is also useful for tracking invisible game objects (game objects that are not rendered). Use this method to decide if those debug lines should be rendered or not.
        Parameters:
        renderCustomDebugLines - whether custom debug lines are rendered

      • destroyPhysicsBody2d

        public void destroyPhysicsBody2d(com.badlogic.gdx.physics.box2d.Body body)
        This is the recommended way to destroy a box2d physics body. The bodies are not destroyed immediately; they are queued until the current frame is completed before they get destroyed. NEVER MANUALLY DELETE A BODY; IT COULD BREAK THE SIMULATION AND CRASH THE GAME
        Parameters:
        body - the body to destroy

      • getPhysicsWorld2d

      • setVelocityIterations

        public void setVelocityIterations(int velocityIterations)
        Sets the velocity iterations for physics simulation. Highly values produces more realistic simulations but higher values also eat up processing power. Defaults to 8. Change it only when necessary.
        Parameters:
        velocityIterations - the velocity iterations for physics simulation.

      • getVelocityIterations

        public int getVelocityIterations()
        Returns:
        the velocity iterations for physics simulation.

      • setPositionIterations

        public void setPositionIterations(int positionIterations)
        Sets the position iterations for physics simulation. Highly values produces more realistic simulations but higher values also eat up processing power. Defaults to 3. Change it only when necessary.
        Parameters:
        positionIterations - the position iterations for physics simulation.

      • pauseForTransition

        public void pauseForTransition()
        Called when this scene needs to pause before scenes are switched. This is useful for pausing stuffs that you don't need to be active during transition. This will be called even if no transition animation is set.

      • newSpriteObject

        public GameObject newSpriteObject(java.lang.String tag,
                                  com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextureRegion sprite,
                                  WorldUnits worldUnits)
        A convenient method for quickly creating a game object that renders a sprite (TextureRegion). The returned game object is not added to the scene; you have to add it yourself!
        Parameters:
        tag - a tag for the game object.
        sprite - a TextureRegion to render
        worldUnits - a WorldUnits instance used for converting the sprite's pixel dimensions to world units
        Returns:
        the created game object

      • newSpriteObject

        public GameObject newSpriteObject(java.lang.String tag,
                                  com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextureRegion sprite)
        A convenient method for quickly creating a game object that renders a sprite (TextureRegion). The WorldUnits instance of the current main camera will be used for unit conversions. The returned game object is not added to the scene; you have to add it yourself!
        Parameters:
        tag - a tag for the game object.
        sprite - a TextureRegion to render
        Returns:
        the created game object

        the created game object

      • newSpriteObject

        public GameObject newSpriteObject(java.lang.String tag,
                                  com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Texture sprite)
        A convenient method for quickly creating a game object that renders a sprite (TextureRegion). The WorldUnits instance of the current main camera will be used for unit conversions. The returned game object is not added to the scene; you have to add it yourself!
        Parameters:
        tag - a tag for the game object.
        sprite - a Texture to render. The entire texture will be rendered!
        Returns:
        the created game object

      • newSpriteObject

        public GameObject newSpriteObject(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Texture sprite)
        A convenient method for quickly creating a game object that renders a sprite (TextureRegion). The WorldUnits instance of the current main camera will be used for unit conversions. The returned game object is not added to the scene; you have to add it yourself!
        Parameters:
        sprite - a Texture to render. The entire texture will be rendered!
        Returns:
        the created game object
